abstract.text: Review an example that represents the temporal position of 5 seconds of 48kHz PCM audio encoded in a 48kHz AAC sound track.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Consider the following example of a typical case of PCM source sound data to be encoded as AAC:

The goal is to represent the temporal position of 5 seconds of 48kHz PCM audio encoded in a 48kHz AAC sound track. Assume a media timescale of 48000 and an encoder delay of 2112. For convenience, assume a movie timescale of 48000 as well.
Source PCM audio data prior to encoding:
Duration in timescale ticks: 240000 (with media timescale the same as sample rate)
AAC in the encoded sound track:
Number of AAC packets: 237 (=((2112+240000) / 1024) rounded up to an integer value)

The transformation from source PCM to encoded AAC results in a sound track with 237 AAC media samples corresponding to 242688 PCM audio samples if decoded and presented in its entirety. Of that total, only 240000 audio samples of source starting at sample offset 2112 (skipping the first 2111 samples) are to be presented. From this, the edit list atom and sample group atom described in the Track structures section below are used to represent the encoder delay.
Based on the Audio data section above, the following
are used to represent the encoder delay.
The edit list atom contains this data:
The edit list atom contains this

For this example, the conventional encoder delay value of 2112 audio samples has been used. Alternative encoder delay values can also be explicitly represented with this mechanism, depending upon codec implementation.
The sample group description atom contains this
Recall that the payload data value could be an alternative value, depending upon the particular codec in use.
is typical for current AAC codecs.
(number of AAC packets representing the encoder delay, original audio samples, and remainder audio samples)
(corresponds to first and only entry in the sample group description atom’s payload data table for these sample units)
Other things to note from this example:

You cannot use the edit list by itself to determine the encoder delay or remainder sample count. The sample group atoms provide the encoder delay. The placement of the end of the edit in a compressed audio packet allows calculation of the remainder samples.
If the encoder delay was the theoretical minimum for AAC of 1024, then the media time field value in the edit list table data shown in this example would be 1024, not 2112.

abstract.text: Position a source audio signal in a sound track to handle encoder delay.

doc://com.apple.qtff/documentation/Quick.title: Audio priming-handling encoder delay in AAC

abstract.text: AAC requires data beyond the source PCM audio samples in order to correctly encode and decode audio samples due to the nature of the encoding algorithm.
Implicit encoder delay uses the most common delay of 2112 audio samples.

doc://com.apple.qtff/documentation/Quick.title: Historical solution for implicit encoder delay

abstract.text: Store different types of media data, including video, sound, subtitles, and more.
Store compressed and uncompressed audio data in QuickTime movies.
Use sample group structures to represent encoder delay for AAC sound tracks.

doc://com.apple.qtff/documentation/Quick.title: Representing encoder delay with track structures

abstract.text: Trim the silent priming samples to preserve correct synchronization.
Represent encoder delay explicitly with an edit list atom and sample group structures.

abstract.text: An object-oriented file format for the storage and exchange of digital media between devices, applications, and operating systems.
An atom that maps from a time in a movie to a time in a media, and ultimately to media data.
An array of 32-bit values, grouped into entries containing 3 values each.
Three bytes of space for flags.
A 32-bit integer that specifies the number of entries in the edit list atom.
A 32-bit integer that specifies the number of bytes in this edit list atom.
A 32-bit integer that identifies the atom type.
A 1-byte specification of the version of this edit list atom.
An atom that associates a sample with a sample group description.
A 32-bit integer giving the number of entries in the table data that follows.
A 3-byte reserved space.
A 32-bit integer identifying the grouping type.
A 32-bit integer that specifies the number of bytes in this sample-to-group atom.
A table of sample count and group description index pairs.
A 32-bit integer that identifies the atom type.
A 1-byte specification of the version of this sample-to-group atom.
An atom that gives information about the characteristics of sample groups.
A 32-bit integer indicating the length of the group entry in the payload data.
A 32-bit integer giving the number of entries in the payload data field.
A 3-byte reserved space.
A 32-bit integer that identifies the grouping type of this sample group description.
A 16-bit signed integer giving the roll distance.
A 32-bit integer that specifies the number of bytes in this sample group description atom.
A 32-bit integer that identifies the atom type.
A 1-byte specification of the version of this sample group description.
